body.p: The deep veins of the upper limbs have similar courses and names as their companion arteries. However, most of these veins are paired and run alongside their accompanying artery. The large superficial veins in the upper limbs are clearly visible just below the skin.

p.term: Major Veins of the Upper Limbs*

tr.td: Paired radial veins begin at the deep palmar venous arches that drain the palmar metacarpal veins in the palms
Paired ulnar veins begin at the superficial palmar venous arches, which drain the common palmar digital veins and proper palmar digital veins in the fingers
Forearms, elbow joints, upper limbs, humerus
Paired brachial veins merge with the basilic veins to form the axillary veins
Upper limbs, axillae, superolateral chest wall
Continuations of the axillary veins; Merge with the internal jugular veins to form the brachiocephalic veins
The cephalic veins begin on the lateral side of the dorsal venous arch, a plexus of veins formed by the dorsal metacarpal veins that drain the dorsal digital veins of the fingers

At the crook of the elbow, the basilic veins are connected to the cephalic veins by the median cubital vein that drains the forearm; The median cubital vein is often used to draw blood or inject intravenous medications; In the axilla, the basilic veins merge with the brachial veins to form the axillary veins
The median antebrachial vein runs between the radial and ulnar veins in the forearm; Ends at the elbow by entering either the basilic or cephalic vein

body.p: *Some veins of the upper limbs also drain structures of the thorax.
